unnormalised: Okay, buckle up, buttercups! We're diving headfirst into the chaotic, caffeine-fueled world of software development. It's a realm where "deadline" is a four-letter word (or maybe eight, depending on how many coffees you've had), and sleep is a luxury reserved for mythical creatures like unicorns and senior management.
normalised: Okay, buckle up, buttercups! We are diving headfirst into the chaotic, caffeine-fueled world of software development. It is a realm where "deadline" is a four-letter word, or maybe eight, depending on how many coffees you have had, and sleep is a luxury reserved for mythical creatures like unicorns and senior management.

unnormalised: First, let's address the elephant in the room, or rather, the bug in the code: testing. Oh, testing. It's like that awkward family reunion where everyone pretends to like each other, but deep down, you know Auntie Shanti is secretly judging your life choices. In software, testing is where you pretend your code works flawlessly until it dramatically explodes in a spectacular display of errors. "It worked on my machine!" is the programmer's equivalent of "The dog ate my homework." We all know that machine is a meticulously crafted, unicorn-powered environment that bears absolutely no resemblance to the real world. And don't even get me started on the dreaded "regression testing". Suddenly a feature from 2005 breaks because you added a comment in line 789. Classic.
normalised: First, let us address the elephant in the room, or rather, the bug in the code: testing. Oh, testing. It is like that awkward family reunion where everyone pretends to like each other, but deep down, you know Auntie Shanti is secretly judging your life choices. In software, testing is where you pretend your code works flawlessly until it dramatically explodes in a spectacular display of errors. "It worked on my machine!" is the programmer's equivalent of "The dog ate my homework." We all know that machine is a meticulously crafted, unicorn-powered environment that bears absolutely no resemblance to the real world. And do not even get me started on the dreaded "regression testing". Suddenly a feature from two thousand and five breaks because you added a comment in line seven hundred and eighty nine. Classic.

unnormalised: Then there's the glorious world of version control. Git is our best friend, our confidante, and the only reason we haven't lost our sanity completely. However, even Git can't save you from the horrors of merge conflicts. Picture this: you've been working on a feature for 72 hours straight ( fueled by copious amounts of chai and Maggi), only to discover that someone else decided to rewrite the entire file using Klingon as their primary coding language. Cue the existential dread. Good luck resolving that, buddy! The command "git push --force" should only be used in the most dire of situations, such as when your boss is threatening to replace your keyboard with a brick.
normalised: Then there is the glorious world of version control. G-I-T is our best friend, our confidante, and the only reason we have not lost our sanity completely. However, even G-I-T can not save you from the horrors of merge conflicts. Picture this: you have been working on a feature for seventy two hours straight, fueled by copious amounts of chai and Maggi, only to discover that someone else decided to rewrite the entire file using Klingon as their primary coding language. Cue the existential dread. Good luck resolving that, buddy! The command "git push force" should only be used in the most dire of situations, such as when your boss is threatening to replace your keyboard with a brick.

unnormalised: Let’s talk about documentation. *laughs hysterically* Oh wait you thought I was serious. We all know software documentation is like a ghost; everyone talks about it, but nobody’s ever actually seen it. It’s rumored to exist, but the evidence is sketchy at best. Even when documentation *is* provided, it's often out of date, incomplete, or written in a language only aliens can comprehend. You have 2 options - decipher the code with help from stackoverflow at 3 AM, or call Rakesh at 123-456-7890 (ext. 404) because his contact is somehow still on that old Wiki page.
normalised: Let us talk about documentation. Laughs hysterically. Oh wait you thought I was serious. We all know software documentation is like a ghost; everyone talks about it, but nobody is ever actually seen it. It is rumored to exist, but the evidence is sketchy at best. Even when documentation is provided, it is often out of date, incomplete, or written in a language only aliens can comprehend. You have two options - decipher the code with help from stackoverflow at three A-M, or call Rakesh at one two three - four five six - seven eight nine zero, extension four zero four, because his contact is somehow still on that old Wiki page.

unnormalised: Speaking of Stack Overflow, let's be real: we've all copy-pasted code from that site without fully understanding what it does. It's like performing a magic trick: you wave your hands, mutter some incantations, and suddenly the problem disappears! Until, of course, it resurfaces later, causing even more chaos than before. But hey, at least you got to deliver your code on time, right? Nobody will ever know you’ve used a function named “do_not_touch_this_or_it_explodes()” from user ‘TechGuru69’.
normalised: Speaking of Stack Overflow, let us be real: we have all copy-pasted code from that site without fully understanding what it does. It is like performing a magic trick: you wave your hands, mutter some incantations, and suddenly the problem disappears! Until, of course, it resurfaces later, causing even more chaos than before. But hey, at least you got to deliver your code on time, right? Nobody will ever know you have used a function named “do_not_touch_this_or_it_explodes()” from user ‘TechGuru sixty nine’.

unnormalised: And finally, let’s appreciate the “Agile” methodology. In theory, it promotes flexibility and adaptability. In practice, it often translates to endless meetings, pointless sprint reviews, and the constant pressure to deliver the impossible in unreasonably short timeframes. Your PM, Priya, wants to know why you've only completed 2 story points out of 100 and she needs answers by EOD (end of day). Remember the sprint planning, when everything was clearly defined with perfectly scoped user stories? Yea, those were the days.
normalised: And finally, let us appreciate the “Agile” methodology. In theory, it promotes flexibility and adaptability. In practice, it often translates to endless meetings, pointless sprint reviews, and the constant pressure to deliver the impossible in unreasonably short timeframes. Your P-M, Priya, wants to know why you have only completed two story points out of one hundred and she needs answers by E-O-D, end of day. Remember the sprint planning, when everything was clearly defined with perfectly scoped user stories? Yea, those were the days.

unnormalised: But despite all the frustrations, the late nights, and the constant battles with broken code, there's something undeniably satisfying about software development. It's like solving a complex puzzle, creating something from nothing, and watching your code come to life. And let's be honest, the sheer amount of inside jokes and shared misery creates a bond that's stronger than any algorithm. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a bug to squash and approximately 2000 lines of code to review. Wish me luck! Maybe I should ask my colleague Mr. Sharma to take a look, his employee id is 987654321.
normalised: But despite all the frustrations, the late nights, and the constant battles with broken code, there is something undeniably satisfying about software development. It is like solving a complex puzzle, creating something from nothing, and watching your code come to life. And let us be honest, the sheer amount of inside jokes and shared misery creates a bond that is stronger than any algorithm. Now, if you will excuse me, I have a bug to squash and approximately two thousand lines of code to review. Wish me luck! Maybe I should ask my colleague Mister Sharma to take a look, his employee I-D is nine eight seven six five four three two one.
